title: Gidole sans
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317110824im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Lettering_5376.png)

I'm creating this and would love some feedback. The typeface will be free and with multiple weights when done.

I haven't done any kerning and the spacing is very rough. Focus right now is on getting the glyphs as I want them and trying to do some optical corrections.

See the pdf's for more detail and sample text.

Just snagged it off the git and immediately tripped over a trap: The Windows descender value (at least on my WinXP machine) has the axis reversed – negative values lie _above_ the baseline.

@ Te: could you try the latest version [https://github.com/gidole/sans/blob/master/Resources/Gidole-Regular.ttf?...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317110824/https:/github.com/gidole/sans/blob/master/Resources/Gidole-Regular.ttf?raw=true "https://github.com/gidole/sans/blob/master/Resources/Gidole-Regular.ttf?raw=true")

Same problem, Andreas. You have your WinDescent set at -200 when it should be 200.

Also, your WinAscent is set at 800, when I believe it should be 667.

Ok, I'm very new to font designing so I misread this guide a bit: [http://designwithfontforge.com/en-US/Line\_Spacing.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317110824/http:/designwithfontforge.com/en-US/Line_Spacing.html "http://designwithfontforge.com/en-US/Line\_Spacing.html")

If I change the ascent, should I change the value in the general value too? Which would give me a new EM size, no?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317110824im_/http:/typophile.com/files/general_5724.png)

Sorry, Andreas, forget what I said earlier - I was in a hurry and only looking at the basic characters, not the whole font.

You'll need the WinAscent value a bit higher than the uppermost part of your tallest glyph, including diacritics. The tallest glyph is currently /A ring acute/ (Unicode 01FA) at 1085. So, the WinAscent value for Gidole needs to be a little above that figure.

The WinDescent should be set lower than the glyph with the lowest node, which is currently /g cedilla/ (Unicode 0123) at -385. However, this glyph is usually represented as a /g/ with something like a /comma/ on top. See [this page](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317110824/http:/www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/0123/fontsupport.htm) and click on the 'view' link alongside each font to see how they treat this character.

If you change your /g cedilla/ to match those in that list, your /A ogonek/ will become your lowest glyph, with a node at -202. You need to allow a little extra room, but enter the value as a positive one, not a negative one.

As for setting up the metrics in FontForge, I'm afraid I don't use it so can't be absolutely sure about the 'General' value you're referring to.

Do make sure you iron out the curve kinks, a clean and monolinear sans is particularly sensitive to those things. There are tools available that help with that.

Is /M somewhat asymmetric?

Have you considered a wider /t, with a more pronounced bottom curve?

One thing I don't like about DIN is the parentheses, which rather look like brackets. Have you tried a simpler, rounder arc shape for those?
